article.h1: ğœ¸(*)â¢ğœ¸(*)superscriptğœ¸superscriptğœ¸bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:bold-( MULOP:bold-times CLOSE:bold-) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:bold-( MULOP:bold-times CLOSE:bold-) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} reactions at high energies111submitted to proceedings of the Durham Collider Workshop, Durham, UK, 22-26 September 1999

span.span: A Donnachieâ€ Â and S SÃ¶ldner-Remboldâ€¡

div.p: The energy available for Î³(*)â¢Î³(*)superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} physics at LEP2 is opening a new window on the study of diffractive phenomena, both non-perturbative and perturbative. We discuss some of the uncertainties and problems connected with the experimental measurements and their interpretation.

Diffractive phenomena occur in each of untagged, single-tagged and double-tagged photon-photon reactions via the total hadronic Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section, ÏƒÎ³â¢Î³subscriptğœğ›¾ğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma}; the structure function of the real photon, F2Î³superscriptsubscriptğ¹2ğ›¾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} (or equivalently the Î³*â¢Î³superscriptğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma\gamma^{*}\gamma cross-section); and the total hadronic Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section, ÏƒÎ³*â¢Î³*subscriptğœsuperscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} respectively. Thus in principle it is possible to study diffraction continuously from the quasi-hadronic regime dominated by non-perturbative physics to the realm of perturbative QCD with either single or double hard scales.

The total hadronic Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section was measured at LEP in the ranges 5â‰¤Wâ‰¤1455ğ‘Š145NUMBER:5 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1455\leq W\leq 145Â GeVÂ [1, 2] and 10â‰¤Wâ‰¤11010ğ‘Š110NUMBER:10 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:11010\leq W\leq 110Â GeVÂ [3], where Wğ‘Šitalic-WW is the photon-photon centre-of-mass energy (Fig.Â 1).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: OPAL data at see=161-183subscriptğ‘ ee161183italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:161 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:183\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=161-183Â GeV in comparison to the L3 data at see=130-161subscriptğ‘ ee130161italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:130 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:161\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=130-161Â GeV (a), at see=183subscriptğ‘ ee183italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183Â GeV (b) and at see=189subscriptğ‘ ee189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=189Â GeV (c). In all cases PHOJET was used for the unfolding of detector effects. The continuous line is a fit to the OPAL data, the dashed line a fit to the L3 data at see=183-189subscriptğ‘ ee183189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183-189Â GeV (see text).

div.p: Since the use of different Monte Carlo models (PYTHIAÂ [4] or PHOJETÂ [5]) for the unfolding of detector effects leads to significant shifts of the normalisation, the results of the two experiments are compared using only PHOJET for these corrections222The published OPAL data are given after averaging the PHOJET and the PYTHIA corrected results (Fig.Â 3)..

Both experiments have measured the high energy rise of the total cross-section typical for hadronic interactions. However a faster rise of the total Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section with Wğ‘Šitalic-WW compared to purely hadronic interactions has not been unambiguously observed. This faster rise is predicted by most models for Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma interactions.

To quantify this effect, both experiments have fitted a Donnachie-Landshoff parametrisation of the form ÏƒÎ³â¢Î³=Xâ¢sÏµ+Yâ¢s-Î·subscriptğœğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘ ğœ‚italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-X italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-Y italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma}=Xs^{\epsilon}+Ys^{-\eta} with Î·=0.34ğœ‚0.34italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.34\eta=0.34. The results are Ïµ=0.10Â±0.02italic-Ïµplus-or-minus0.100.02italic-epsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.10 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\epsilon=0.10\pm 0.02Â (OPAL) and Ïµ=0.22Â±0.02italic-Ïµplus-or-minus0.220.02italic-epsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.22 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\epsilon=0.22\pm 0.02Â (L3), where the L3 fit uses only the preliminary data at see=183-189subscriptğ‘ ee183189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183-189Â GeV. The fitted curves are also shown in Fig.Â 1. The L3 result implies a significantly faster rise of the total Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section than in hadron-hadron scattering whereas the OPAL result is consistent with a typical value of Ïµâ‰ˆ0.08italic-Ïµ0.08italic-epsilon RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.08\epsilon\approx 0.08 for a soft Pomeron.

The results are consistent in the kinematic region where the measurements of both experiments overlap. Some discrepancies seem to exist between the L3 measurements at different seesubscriptğ‘ eeitalic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}, both at low and at high Wğ‘Šitalic-WW. The data in the range W<10ğ‘Š10italic-W RELOP:less-than NUMBER:10W<10Â GeV also have large influence on the fitted value of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon due to the large correlation between the Reggeon-Term Yğ‘Œitalic-YY and Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Left plot (L3): number of Î³â¢Î³â†’Ï0â¢Xâ†’ğ›¾ğ›¾superscriptğœŒ0ğ‘‹italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-X\gamma\gamma\to\rho^{0}X events as a function of the visible Wğ‘Šitalic-WW (Wvissubscriptğ‘Švisitalic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start vis POSTSUBSCRIPT:endW_{\rm vis}). Right plots (OPAL): number of selected two-photon events in the range 6<Wvis<1206subscriptğ‘Švis120NUMBER:6 RELOP:less-than italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start vis POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1206<W_{\rm vis}<120Â GeV as a function of the maximum rapidity gap, Î”â¢Î·maxÎ”subscriptğœ‚maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max}, between any two particles (tracks and calorimeter clusters). For the MC, the diffractive events (including quasi-elastic scattering) are shown separately.

div.p: The main problems of this measurement are the resolution effects in the reconstruction of Wğ‘Šitalic-WW from the hadronic final state and the small acceptance for events coming from soft diffractive or quasi-elastic processes (e.g. Î³â¢Î³â†’Ïâ¢Ïâ†’ğ›¾ğ›¾ğœŒğœŒitalic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho italic-rho\gamma\gamma\to\rho\rho) which lead to the large model dependence for the final results. The Wğ‘Šitalic-WW resolution makes it necessary to use unfolding models which introduce large bin-to-bin correlations. The acceptance for soft diffractive and quasi-elastic processes is only 5-15%percentPOSTFIX:percent\%, depending on the Wğ‘Šitalic-WW range and on the MC model usedÂ [3]. For W>20ğ‘Š20italic-W RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:20W>20Â GeV the average polar angle of the pions in Î³â¢Î³â†’Ïâ¢Ïâ†’ğ›¾ğ›¾ğœŒğœŒitalic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho italic-rho\gamma\gamma\to\rho\rho events is less than 100 mrad, well below the tracking coverage of the LEP detectors. L3 has therefore measured inclusive ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho production in Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma events for 3â‰¤Wâ‰¤103ğ‘Š10NUMBER:3 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:103\leq W\leq 10Â GeV. In this Wğ‘Šitalic-WW region large discrepancies between the Monte Carlo models and the data are observed (Fig.Â 2). At higher Wğ‘Šitalic-WW OPAL has studied the maximum rapidity gap Î”â¢Î·maxÎ”subscriptğœ‚maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max} between any two particles (tracks and calorimeter clusters) in an event. At high Î”â¢Î·maxÎ”subscriptğœ‚maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max}, where diffractive events are expected to contribute, the data lie above the Monte Carlo models and PHOJET is closer to the data than PYTHIA.

Soft processes like quasi-elastic scattering (Î³â¢Î³â†’Vâ¢Vâ†’ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‰italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-V italic-V\gamma\gamma\to VV, where Vğ‘‰italic-VV is a vector meson), single-diffractive scattering (Î³â¢Î³â†’Vâ¢Xâ†’ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‹italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-V italic-X\gamma\gamma\to VX, where Xğ‘‹italic-XX is a low mass hadronic system) or double-diffractive scattering (Î³â¢Î³â†’X1â¢X2â†’ğ›¾ğ›¾subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹2italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma\gamma\to X_{1}X_{2}) are modelled by both generators. The cross-sections are obtained by fitting a Regge parametrisation to pp, pâ¢pÂ¯pÂ¯pATOM:p OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start ATOM:p ARG:end\mbox{p}\overline{\mbox{p}} and Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammap data and by assuming Regge factorisation, i.e.Â universal couplings of the Pomeron to the hadronic fluctuations of the photon. In both generators the quasi-elastic cross-section is about 5-6%5percent6NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTFIX:percent5-6\%, the single-diffractive cross-section about 8-12%8percent12NUMBER:8 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12 POSTFIX:percent8-12\% and the double-diffractive cross-section about 3-4%3percent4NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTFIX:percent3-4\% of ÏƒÎ³â¢Î³subscriptğœğ›¾ğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} for W>10ğ‘Š10italic-W RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:10W>10Â GeV. In the Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma data no clear diffractive signal has yet been observed and it would be very useful to find experimental variables which could give a better discrimination between diffractive and non-diffractive events at LEP and which could be used to test the Monte Carlo models.

section.h2: 3 The hard Pomeron model and the dipole formalism

div.p: As the energies and virtualities available at LEP are comparatively moderate it is necessary to take into account diffractive and non-diffractive contributions. There are two main sources of the non-diffractive contributions: Reggeon exchange and the quark box diagram with pointlike couplings of the photon. In Regge language the latter gives rise to a fixed pole in the complex angular momentum plane, so it is not dual to Regge exchange and it is correct to add the two contributions. The box diagram is well definedÂ [6]. The Regge contribution to F2Î³superscriptsubscriptğ¹2ğ›¾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} can be estimatedÂ [7] using the DGLAP evolved pion structure function and naive VMD. This can be extended to both the Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma and Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-sections assuming factorization [8]. In the dipole approach to the small-xğ‘¥italic-xx structure function of the proton it has become increasingly clear that the nominally perturbative regime still contains some non-perturbative contribution [9, 10, 11]. A specific model has been proposed in terms of two Pomerons [12, 13, 14]. This combines a hard Pomeron with an intercept of about 1.44 together with the soft Pomeron of hadronic physics with an intercept of about 1.08.

An analogous approach is that ofÂ [15] in which the hard Pomeron is modelled within the BFKL framework. A similar conclusion is reached, that for diffractive reactions on a hadronic target the purely perturbative regime is not reached until rather large values of Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}.

Combining the dipole formalism with the two-Pomeron approach allows predictions to be made for the Î³(*)â¢Î³(*)superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} cross-sections [8]. An appropriate model for soft Pomeron exchange is the eikonal approach [16] to high energy scattering. It is particularly suited to incorporate the non-perturbative aspects of QCD which are treated in the Model of the Stochastic VacuumÂ [17, 18, 19], which approximates the infrared part of QCD by a Gaussian stochastic process in the colour field strength. The two-Pomeron approach ofÂ [12] has been adapted to the MSV model in [20] and successfully tested for the photo- and electroproduction of vector mesons, and for the proton structure function over a wide range of xğ‘¥italic-xx and Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: The total hadronic photon-photon cross-section ÏƒÎ³â¢Î³subscriptğœğ›¾ğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} (in nb) as function of Wğ‘Šitalic-WW (in GeV).

Figure 4: The photon structure function F2Î³superscriptsubscriptğ¹2ğ›¾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} as function of xğ‘¥italic-xx. a) âŸ¨Q2âŸ©=1.9delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘„21.9OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.9\langle Q^{2}\rangle=1.9Â GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, (L3: triangles, OPAL: diamonds and boxes); b) âŸ¨Q2âŸ©â‰ˆ15delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘„215OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:15\langle Q^{2}\rangle\approx 15Â GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, (ALEPH: stars, L3: triangles, OPAL: diamonds and boxes).

Figure 5: The virtual photon cross-section ÏƒÎ³*â¢Î³*subscriptğœsuperscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} in nb. L3 data points are shown.

div.p: With all parameters determined from hadronic scattering and deep inelastic scattering, in principle the model can then predict all the Î³(*)â¢Î³(*)superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} cross-sectionsÂ [8]. The only caveat is that the Pomeron contribution to ÏƒÎ³â¢Î³subscriptğœğ›¾ğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} is rather sensitive to the effective light quark mass mqsubscriptğ‘šqitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\rm q} entering the photon wave function, varying as âˆ¼1/mq4similar-toabsent1superscriptsubscriptğ‘šq4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1/m_{\rm q}^{4}. This is illustrated in Figs.Â 3a and b which show separately the L3Â [1, 2] and OPALÂ [3] data and the Pomeron model with mq=210subscriptğ‘šq210italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:210m_{\rm q}=210 MeV and 200 MeV respectively, together with the other contributions to the total cross-section. These values of mqsubscriptğ‘šqitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\rm q} are within the range previously determined, and the choice does not affect the predictions away from Q2=0superscriptğ‘„20italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0Q^{2}=0. Comparison of the predictions with F2Î³superscriptsubscriptğ¹2ğ›¾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} at âŸ¨Q2âŸ©=1.9delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘„21.9OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.9\langle Q^{2}\rangle=1.9 and 1515NUMBER:1515 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} are shown in Figs.Â 4 a and b respectively. They clearly provide a satisfactory description of the data. However comparison with ÏƒÎ³*â¢Î³*subscriptğœsuperscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} is much less successful as is evident in Figs.Â 5a and b, for which âŸ¨Q12âŸ©=âŸ¨Q22âŸ©=3.5delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘„12delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘„223.5OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.5\langle Q_{1}^{2}\rangle=\langle Q_{2}^{2}\rangle=3.5 and 14 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} respectively.

The significance of these results is that a well-tried model of diffraction which successfully describes high-energy hadronic interactions, vector meson photo- and electroproduction, deep inelastic scattering at small xğ‘¥italic-xx, the real Î³â¢Î³ğ›¾ğ›¾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section and the structure function of the real photon fails to predict correctly the Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section even at quite modest photon virtualities. This is clearly due to the fact that, uniquely among these various processes, the Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} interaction involves two small dipoles. It emphasizes the importance of the Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section as a probe of the dynamics of the perturbative hard Pomeron.

section.h2: 4 ğœ¸*â¢ğœ¸*superscriptğœ¸superscriptğœ¸bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:bold-times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:bold-times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} scattering in the BFKL formalism

div.p: The application of the BFKL formalism to Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} scattering has been considered by [21-26]. In the BFKL formalism there is a problem at LLO in setting the two mass scales on which the cross-section depends: the mass Î¼2superscriptğœ‡2italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{2} at which the strong coupling Î±ssubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{s} is evaluated and the mass Qs2superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘ 2italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ_{s}^{2} which provides

figure.figcaption: Figure 6: Cross-section for the process e+â¢e-â†’e+â¢e-â¢Î³*â¢Î³*â†’e+â¢e-â†’superscriptesuperscriptesuperscriptesuperscriptesuperscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾â†’superscriptesuperscripteATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-}\to\mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-}\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}\to% \mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-}Â hadrons as a function of Yâ‰ˆlnâ¡(W2/Q12â¢Q22)ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Š2superscriptsubscriptğ‘„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘„22italic-Y RELOP:approximately-equals OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm OPEN:( italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)Y\approx\ln(W^{2}/Q_{1}^{2}Q_{2}^{2}) (for exact kinematic cuts seeÂ [28] and [29]).

div.p: the scale for the high energy logarithms. The result is very sensitive to these parameters, and Brodsky et al [23, 24] showed that changing Î¼2â†’4â¢Î¼2â†’superscriptğœ‡24superscriptğœ‡2italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{2}\to 4\mu^{2} or Qs2â†’Qs2/4â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘ 24italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4Q_{s}^{2}\to Q_{s}^{2}/4 alters the predicted cross-section by factors of âˆ¼1/4similar-toabsent14RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\sim 1/4 or âˆ¼4similar-toabsent4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4\sim 4 respectively in a typical LEP experiment. An additional uncertainty is due to the correct treatment of the production of massive charm quarks.

In an attempt to overcome the scale problem, Boonekamp et al [25] take a phenomenological approach to estimate the NNLO effects, making use of a fit [27] to the proton structure function using the QCD dipole picture of BFKL dynamics. This reduces both the size of the BFKL cross-section and its energy dependence. Fig.Â 6 shows the preliminary OPAL measurement of the double-tag e+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}e-FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-} cross-section in the range Q12â‰ˆQ22â‰ˆ5-25superscriptsubscriptğ‘„12superscriptsubscriptğ‘„22525italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:25Q_{1}^{2}\approx Q_{2}^{2}\approx 5-25Â GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}Â [28] compared to the LO BFKL calculation and to the HO model ofÂ Boonekamp et al.Â [25]. The cross-section predicted by PHOJETÂ [5] is also shown. The L3 collaboration has extracted the Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section using the photon flux for transverse photons (Fig.Â 6)Â [29]. The QPM part (box diagram) has been subtracted (the unsubtracted cross-section is shown in Fig.Â 5). The L3 data is compared to a LO BFKL prediction and to the two-gluon exchange cross-section (here called one-gluon) based on Ref.Â [24] and to a fit of the hard Pomeron intercept. A calculationÂ [26] of subleading corrections to the BFKL equation shows that these are significant at LEP energies, and with the inclusion of the soft Pomeron a reasonable description of the L3 data is obtained.

Both experiments observe that the cross-section predicted by PHOJET, which does not contain BFKL effects, is consistent with the data within the large experimental errors, whereas LO BFKL predictions overestimate the Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section by a large factor. However, the large theoretical uncertainties discussed above need to be taken into account.

In the last year difficulties have emerged with the application of the Altarelli-Parisi equation to the evolution of the proton structure function at small xğ‘¥italic-xx and with the BFKL equation. These are summarised inÂ [30]. One of the questions is whether intrinsically non-perturbative contributions are involved, even at quite large Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}, because of the intrinsically non-perturbative target. This complication is in principle avoided in Î³*â¢Î³*superscriptğ›¾superscriptğ›¾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} reactions as both are dominated at large Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2} by the perturbative part of the photon wave function. This may be happening at quite modest values of Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}, providing LEP with an excellent opportunity to clarify this question.
